title: Thorough analysis of log data with dependency rules: Practical solutions and theoretical challenges

author: Wilhelmiina Hämäläinen, School of Computing, University of Eastern Finland

segmentation: Good morning everybody, and topic of my presentation is really the likely problems you are going to meet when you try to analyze log data with dependency rules and my approach here is twofold.
So this practical solution part could be described as the lessons learned from practice.
I worked nearly two years as a data miner for biologists, and during that time my main task was to analyze log data and the goal was of course to infer new knowledge on.
Animals behavior, health care welfare and that kind of thing.
So we had a lot of different kinds of devices.
And of course other kind of measurement.

And during that time I did not have time to begin to develop any new algorithms, so I just had to take the existing tools as a black box and what I could do I try to invent that kind of clever pre processing and post perverse dentrix so that I could handle the problems with that or switch exist and they work when you have relatively circuit simple date.

But of course there are fundamental problems and this is not the most sensible way to do things, so this surgical challenges part here is that I try to rise your interest to those challenges where we shoot in with new algorithms, and even before we go to algorithms, we should in fact define the appropriate statistical significance tests, because before that we don't know what kind of patterns to search for.
OK, anyway, before I go to this problems either recall your pre flip.
What is typical aglae data like?
And then what are dependencies errors?
And in a log data you of course have timestamps always, so we know the beginning and end time of the session, and then we have a user and device identifiers, even type.
Objects which are accessed and their campaign or other kind of characteristics.
So this can be like describing the other variables, or they can be derived from the combination or other variables, maybe using some background knowledge.
Or they may even be there from other log records or sets of records together.
And here's a real world example from dairy cows feeding automate, so the lock record itself.
It contest just this box here.
So we handle variables for the beginning and end date and time the cow identifier automatron identifier feed type and the amount of feet which was consumed during the event.
And from this we can of course easily derive that kind of things like a weekday, which is quite important.
In fact, for the animals behavior.
And since we had several experiment.
So which experiment.
It was and the date during the experiment.
And when we are also giving the time so we can easily derive the duration of the event?

And when we had a combination of the cows and an automated identifier, we could infer whether it was just a normal eighting where it was actually stealing, whether there was a robber eating, or whether it was a victim.
When we use the background information on the cows, we could also add here variables on the predam the cows because they can have different size, different breeds, character type draw.
We had classes like every cow nerd lady so on.
And the number carvings.
It's also very important because it correlates with the social status of the cost.

And given this automaton identifier, we also could add here information on the location of the automated and therefore we at least in principle knew what was happening in the neighborhood at the same time.
OK, that's about LA.
Date, then dependency rules.
So dependence rule X indicates a expresses statistical dependencies between a certain variable sex and the single variable A.
And the goodness of dependencies is evaluated by statistical goodness measures.
So typically we have P values, key squared mutual information, that kind of message.
But what is important?
We don't have any minimum friction thresholds, so these are not Association rules.
And the important difference is that we are not expressing just frequently occurring attributes, but really statistically significant dependencies.
And since these frequency thresholds are not used, it also means that we can find globally optimal results.
And ideally the dependency rules should also be nonredundant, and there are several interpretations with this.
Non redundancy means the basic ideas are saying so.
The rule should contain only that kind of those attributes with contribute to the statistical dependencies significantly.
And here's an example if you already know statistical dependencies between rainy days and wet dogs, then small specific.
Dependency rule like Rainy day and autumn indicates a wet dog hardly as anything new because we know that on autumn we often have rainy days.
But whether this most Pacific rule is redundant or not?
It depends on how we have defined dependency rules.

So what is the underlying statistical model and how we have measured their significance, and only that we have defined how to measure the significance of of knew or extra attributes which maybe make the dependency look better.
So dependency rules are very attractive, especially as the first step.
Data analyzes tool.
The reason is that they can handle efficiently extremely large dimensional data and still produce globally optimal results.

And this is a clear benefit in the first step mining, because you don't know yet which variables you could prune out, but instead you would like to if possible, during all possibly interesting features and try everything.
However, the main restriction is that all these nice efficient algorithms and tools they assume that you have binary data.
And also the form of the rules can be quite restricted.
So this now leads to.
Problems.
And the problems when analyzing log data can be roughly divided into three categories.
So the first main problem is how to balance between groups and individuals.
So the idea is that in the same time we would like to find both common friends, individual regularity's and peculiarities.
The second main problem is how to discretize numerical an parodic variables optimized and the periodic variables.
I mean that kind of variables which get cyclic values like hours of the day or days of the week.
So the same values are repeating again and again.
And then third, how to extract attributes from interesting dimensions of the date.
So when we want to take into account the spatial and temporal context of those events and also interactions between the events?
And this post problem main problem balancing between groups and individuals has free subproblems.

So first incorporating attribute hierarchies other part time work is very useful because they can be used to express or integrate background information in the log data and on the other hand they can describe statistical dependencies on different abstraction levels.
Second, how to handle individual differences in numerical variables?
And the problem here is that numerical variables are extremely sensitive to individual variation, and it's therefore very hard to chat when the value is normal or exceptional for certain individual.
A shirt on reference group or the whole population.
So in practice it means that we need to derive new kind over maybe normalized features before we go to any kind of discrimination or any further.
And then food.

The problem that we would like to have recently support that kind of church where we can focus on only individuals or exceptional events, even if they are rare and are not among the most significant dependencies.
So in practice a user would like to give Chester List of interesting attributes we should search for only those dependencies which involve those attributes.

So if here we have a A is interesting attribute we would like to first of all find that kind of rules like classification rules, whether a is in the consequense, but also that kind of rules where we have a here in the condition.
So we have like a.
Additional independence between Q and be given a, so these are also very very interesting dependencies and unfortunately there are no efficient algorithms currently.
How to do?
How to support these kind of queries?
Here I'm not going to the details of these last two problems, so if you are interested you can read more more paper, but let's look at this first Sam problem.
Little bit further.
So here's an example I already mentioned that we had classified accounts character into five different categories.
We had robber thief.
Every call, so like a normal call nerd and lady.
And you can think that all these character types, they are super concepts and these color identifiers with just our which individual how it works.
Unlike a sub concepts under there and for example count 21 was classified both as a rubber under safe.
So these individuals can be under several of those upper concepts.
And because we were interested in the stealing behavior of the cows, so we also divided this character types into two groups.
So we had circled criminals which could be robbers or thieves.
And everybody else there called soccer decent cows.
So now the problem is that how should we compare that kind of rose like deceive and Q indicates a?
Or count 21 Q indicates a or if you want to go to one step further.
For example, see for rubber, also called criminal acuity, God say.

So the challenge here is that first of all we should define and operate statistical significance test so that we know that which level of the dependency contest redundant information and where is the most significant non redundant information or rule to search.
And only after that we can begin to disarm the search.
In the paper I have described that kind of tricks which can be used with the existing tools.
If you have relatively small hierarchies and if the tool chest support redundancy constraint and a couple of other simple constraints and you just create new extra ticket.
So sometimes this is to solve, but there are really interesting challenges left.

The second main problem was how to discretize numerical Anna periodic variables and the problem here is that different discrete chastens can be optimal for different dependencies, so in practice it means that we cannot fix any discrimination in advance.
We cannot use any static descriptions.
So the challenge is that how should we or how could we discretize dynamically during the search so that it would be sufficiently feasible?
And as can be expected, this is computationally very tricky problem and there are no efficient solutions currently.

However, are introducing the paper that kind of simple prepro singtrix which can be used to simulate dynamic discussion, and they work surprisingly well if you just have relatively small number of numerical variables or each of the variables gets relatively few different values.
Otherwise, you're going to cause user course Automic intervals, but it means that after that it's no more guarantee that you find globally optimal results.
They're still better than the static description, but no more guaranteed to be optimal.

And always it's good to keep in mind that if you are interested in only exceptional dependencies, then you can concentrate and exceptional values and just summarize what normal values into in the one either.
And here's just an example of what kind of dependency rules you can find using these tricks.
So I run these experiments working for some program which doesn't support any any.

This could chase, so I just use my pre processing tricks and I have selected your rules which involve the same free variables and the goodness of roses measured professors P. But I report here only the natural logarithm model P. So the smaller the value the better rule.
The best rules here in the top.
And the frequencies are just reported for curiosity.
And as you can see here, the program has really.
It looks like it has iterated between different thresholds for those two variables, and it has finally found the best one.
But in practice it has done.
It's just at the same time for all of this, and we could of course add here post processing trick and just prune out all these truths and report just the best one of that kind of groups of rules.
And then we have this hurt.
Main problem opening interested dimensions and I think this is very exciting.
New research area where I can just like a little bit question surface.
So here the idea is that we are no more interesting individual records, but instead set of events or sets of requests and we would like to infer totally new variables.
And for example, in our house example we had this spatial context we were interested in what was happening in the neighborhood devices.
Temporal context is already more multifaceted, so we can very variables from the event history of an individual over device or the whole clubhouse, and then we of course have social interactions.
So, for example, we can find who are using the devices in the same time or who are not using the same time.
And then sometimes for example, give hints us who are robbing the other couch.
So to conclude, there are practical tricks.
Without sufficient, with relatively so good simple data lock data, but the log data can be really complex, so here just a couple of examples.
First of all, you can think about the log data from web stores, so we have very detailed Market Basket data.
A lot of products, very extensive hierarchies, and we can calculate the lot of different kinds of statistiques.
So numerical variables which describes the products and then we of course have here user profiles, user preferences, and the event history values so it can be very complex.
2nd we have of course, mobile devices, so the location of the device is no more fixed, but it's all the time chance.
And of course there gonna be other sensors, which means that we have many numerical variables which should be handled in the same time.
And then we have this problem of combining log data from different devices and not just log data but also those other measurements which we have done during those experiments.
And here the problem is that the seasons or events are not necessarily occur in the same time, but still they affect its other.

And even if I have here been talking only about log data, which was my motivation, is starting point, we should remember that in fact, many of these problems are important in other heterogeneous real data as well.
OK, thank you.
